title: cockburnspath-woman-meets-her-stem-cell-donor-on-itv-show
story: Laura Regan received a bone marrow transplant in  from an anonymous stem cell donor after being diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukaemia.Laura said that she thought about her donor often, adding: ldquoI knew it wouldnrsquot have been easy for him, having to re-arrange their le around the transplant.The -year-old was discovered by the ITV show This Time Next Year through her blog, in which she records the stages of her recovery.They filmed her saying that she would find her donor and they would appear on the show together a year later ndash which she did.The donor was a -year-old doctor named Simon Bird, and to her surprise they ended up living close to each other in London.ldquoThe first thing I did when I got Simonrsquos details was to look up his address on Google Maps," Laura said."It turned out that he lived just three miles away!ldquoEvery one of my friends told me I would be in tears but on the night, I couldnrsquot stop smiling."Simon was everything Irsquod hoped and imagined in real le and I was just so grateful to him for what hersquod done.ldquoWe were both keen to do the show to raise awareness for the Anthony Nolan Charity, who had helped me find a donor in the first place."Following filming, the pair have kept in touch. Laura said: ldquoWersquove been out for drinks. Wersquore both in long-term relationships, and Simon and his partner have invited me and my partner over for dinner. Wersquove become close.The episode, hosted by Davina McCall, will be aired tomorrowat .pm.

title: east-lothian-council-services-for-hire
story: The council is looking at ways to bring in extra revenue in the next three years by capitalising on its services and the influx of new housing in the county.Burial plots in two new cemeteries will be made available for advance sales as the council re-opens the pre-sale of lairs in Dunbar and Prestonpans, where capacity issues have seen the practice suspended in recent years. New housing developments in the towns have seen plans put forward for new graveyards to cope with the increasing populations.In Prestonpans, a proposed cemetery is included with plans to build  houses at Dolphingstone Farm while in Dunbar plans for a new graveyard at Newtonlees have been approved by the council.A council spokesperson said advance sales were withdrawn in the towns to ensure lairs were available for immediate need as they ran out of space.However, he confirmed: ldquoIt is expected that, as the new provision opens in Prestonpans and Dunbar, we will be in a position to process requests.As further new sites are developed, it is anticipated this option will become more widely available.It is anticipated the move will bring an additional pound, in revenue for the local authority in the next financial year as people queue up to book plots in their home towns.The move is one of a number of ventures which have been given the go-ahead in the councilrsquos budget plans for the next three years to maximise income.It also includes plans to bid to take over factoring contracts for landscaping in new housing developments and offer to install play equipment and areas in the same estates.The local authority is looking to capitalise on the influx of housing into the county, which is seeing up to , new homes being built across its communities.It hopes that it can compete with private factoring firms to take on responsibility for public areas within new housing estates, which developers traditionally hand on to independent factors.And it has budgeted a potential income of up to pound, by providing the commercial service over the next three years, as well as a further pound, by offering to install play areas in the new developments.The council said it was seeking to develop ldquocommercial opportunities across all services.The spokesman said: ldquoGiven the countyrsquos growth agenda, these are areas that we intend to explore.

title: man-who-slept-in-van-after-drinking-avoids-driving-ban
story: Mario Delacruz, , was caught sleeping in his van in an Edinburgh car park after he had been out drinking with friends in the city last year.Delacruz was spotted by police officers sleeping in the passenger seat of his van but they also saw his keys were lying nearby on the driverrsquos seat.The officers woke the Spanish national up and, after noticing he had been drinking alcohol, decided to breathalyse him.The tests showed that Delacruz, of The Promenade, was more than four times the drink-drive limit.Delacruz appeared at Edinburgh Sherf Court, where he pleaded guilty to being in charge of the vehicle at the time on October  last year.Solicitor Peter OrsquoNeill said that his client had been out with friends in the Leith area of the city and had decided to ldquosleep it off before going home the following day.Mr OrsquoNeill said that Delacruz had been in the UK for about five years and had moved to Scotland last July.He currently works as a cleaner and has sold the van he was found sleeping in.The lawyer added: ldquoHe is sorry and knows it should not have happened.Sherf John Cook fined Delacruz pound and told him that he would have  penalty points placed on his licence.Delacruz pleaded guilty to being in charge of a motor vehicle with mcg of alcohol in ml of breath at Nichollfield, Edinburgh, on October  last year. The legal limit is  mcg.

title: conservatives-announce-haddington-by-election-candidate
story: Haddington resident Craig Hoy will represent the Scottish Conservative and Unionist Party at the vote on May .The by-election was triggered by theresignation last week of Councillor Brian Small, who represented the Conservatives.Mr Hoy previously worked in journalism, first with the BBC before setting up several publications, including Holyrood Magazine.More recently, he has joined the development board of a major Scottish charity, which focuses on issues such as fuel poverty among older people.My Hoy was ldquodelighted to have been selected and looking forward to the election.He said: ldquoWith Nicola Sturgeon threatening a second independence referendum, itrsquos more important than ever that we elect a strong voice for Haddington and the Lammermuirs who will stand up to the SNP.ldquoAs a local resident and campaigner, Irsquom confident that I am well placed to do just that, and I look forward to taking our message to voters right across the ward over the coming weeks."And he added: "Our area has a fantastic sense of community and history.ldquoMy aim in this campaign is to meet as many people as possible to find out what their views are and what issues they want me to focus on.Tim Jackson, East Lothian Scottish Conservative Association chairman, was delighted to have secured ldquoa candidate of Craigrsquos calibre for the by-election.He said: ldquoNot only is he passionate about the area, but with his experience in media and business he can bring a lot to the council.ldquoI know he will give his all in the campaign, andelected he will do everything he can to provide a strong voice for everyone living in Haddington and the Lammermuirs.No other party has announced their candidate for the by-election.

title: port-seton-man-offers-to-clean-gardens-of-dog-waste
story: Super Pet Scooper was founded in January by Port Seton man Greg Mahony, of Laburnum Avenue, who will be servicing the East Lothian area for its doggy clear-up needs.ldquoI was looking for a business opportunity in the area, Greg said.ldquoCleaning gardens of dog waste is big in the USA and Canada, and even England, but not around here, so I saw a gap in the marketOriginally from Manchester, Greg and his family fell in love with all East Lothian had to offer, especially when walking his own rescue dog, Rocco. It was then he noticed that dog fouling in the area was becoming an issue.ldquoOur community wants to live in a nice environment, he said.ldquoWe promote responsible ownership, enforce fines and put up signs, but sometimes itrsquos just not enough.ldquoMany dog owners, like myself, always take doggie bags to clean up the waste, but sadly, many owners do not.This was when Greg came up with the idea for Super Pet Scooper.ldquoI never thought Irsquod start a business, but I wanted to do something that would help people and I love animals, especially dogs, so it made sense, he said.ldquoI donrsquot mind cleaning up after dogs, it doesnrsquot bother me! It also gets me out and about on a weekend, as well as a little more income.Greg works during the week for the NHS but has high hopes that he can build his company to a full-time role.ldquoAt the moment, Irsquom only part-time but Irsquom hoping to expand, he said.ldquoI got in touch with East Lothian Council for advice and they were fantastic, helped me get my waste carrier licence and advice on business insurance and things.Despite only being in his first month of business, the -year-old has a few clients and has been getting good reviews across Facebook.ldquoIrsquove had a positive reaction to the company, he said. ldquoI know a lot of people think thatyou have a dog you should be able to clean up after them yourself, but a lot of people canrsquot. They can fall ill or just become unable to move around like they used to, so thatrsquos where I can help.

title: ghost-hunters-heading-to-historic-east-lothian-buildings
story: The two events will be taking place in the coming months.Lisa Tedstill, company owner of UK Ghost Nights said: ldquoItrsquos all about the personal experience, the emotions, and sometimes the giggling and laughing. Itrsquos about the camaraderie. Itrsquos a great way to view history, and there have been many spooky things happening in these places.The night involves a tour of the building by a medium, then the chance to use high-tech ghost hunting equipment for experiments, as well as more standard methods such as seances and spirit boards.ldquoWe like to give people a chance to see and use lots of new things and provide a good mix of the technical and the traditional, added Lisa.ldquoItrsquos great here in East Lothian as there is so much history in these buildings.The ghost hunts are at Dunbar Town House on March  and Cockenzie House on April , both pm-am.

title: pupils-to-enjoy-unique-study-visit-to-oxford-university
story: Exeter College has teamed up with East Lothian Council to bring  third-year pupils to the university for a stay which will allow them to experience first-hand the unique learning techniques and opportunities available there.The project was established by former Councillor East Lothian Brian Small and his son Andrew, who is a doctoral student at the college and came up with the idea.Brian, of Pencaitland, said the pair now hoped to establish an endowment fund to ensure the trip can become an annual event for East Lothian students by providing travel costs and other support.This yearrsquos trip will see the local authority fund travel with the college covering all costs of the stay itself.Mr Small, who resigned from the council last week after branding his fellow Conservative councillors ldquoheartless over the way they dealt with his battle with health issues, said he wanted to make sure money was available to repeat the project every summer.He said: ldquoI am delighted we have been able to start this innovative project as pathways for all our children in East Lothian was always something I was fully committed to as a councillor.ldquoI am now looking to set up an endowment fund to ensure travel costs along with perhaps some other support needs are able to be covered in future years.ldquoIf anyone would like to discuss this further then I would be delighted to talk with them.Two pupils from each of East Lothianrsquos six secondary schools will travel to Oxford in June for the week-long stay.The selected students will live on Exeter Collegersquos historic main site, in the very heart of Oxford, where they will be given a taster experience of what makes an Oxford education.The council said interested pupils were now given a chance to apply for a place in the trip with places awarded by teachers following a selection procedure involving written work.Andrew said: ldquoThis is a fantastic opportunity for pupils from East Lothian to come and learn at one of the worldrsquos greatest educational institutions.ldquoThe weekrsquos activities have been selected to improve pupilsrsquo independent and creative thinking, which we hope will improve their attainment at school and perhaps even plant the seed of aspiration that will motivate pupils to attend the university.ldquoMy hope is that this is just the beginning of a long-standing partnership between the college and East Lothian.ldquoI would like to thank Sir Rick Trainor, Rector of Exeter College and Professor Mac Niocaill, the collegersquos Tutor for Admissions, for their full support. Without them, this partnership would have remained just an idea.Fiona Robertson, head of education, East Lothian Council, said the trip offered a rare opportunity for young people in the county to study at one of the worldrsquos top universities.She said: ldquoI hope the  pupils involved will find it to be an inspirational trip and one which allows them to develop their independent, creative thinking and commitment to learning. I would like to thank Andrew Small and his father, Brian Small, for making this a reality.

title: 1000-sign-petition-over-loss-of-creche-services-at-leisure-centres
story: The organisation manages leisure facilities across the county on behalf of East Lothian Council.However, it has taken the decision to close the creches following a drop in funding.The move has not gone down well with a number of parents, who fear they may have to cancel their gym membershipsthe creche service does not continue.A group of parents met with Iain Gray, East Lothianrsquos MSP, on Monday to discuss the issue.Among them was Sarah Brunton, who regularly uses enjoyleisurersquos facilities in North Berwick, Haddington and Dunbar.The mum-of-four said she had improved her fitness at the facilities since having her children. She said: ldquoItrsquos down to those facilities and being able to have a healthier lestyle.ldquoIt is about not just weight loss but also a mental health aspect. It gives you confidence and a lt after you have done exercise and it is proven that exercise does improve mental health.Mrs Brunton stressed the issue affected ldquoa lot of people and many were considering whether to cancel their membership.Another of those who has signed the online petition is -year-old Erin Malone, who uses the Aubigny Sports Centre, in Haddington, and Tranentrsquos Loch Centre.She said: ldquoThe creche is really important ndash not just for me but my son as well.ldquoMy daughter used it as well and we have been using it for over six years.ldquoIt is a social thing and a mental health thing as well.Lydia Eunson, from Dunbar, uses the sports centre in Dunbar twice a week.She added: ldquoMy husband works away four weeks at a time and I donrsquot have any family near here.ldquoBasically, I could not use the gym unless I paid a babysitter or went to a gym in Edinburgh with a creche.Bill Axon, general manager of enjoyleisure, stressed it was not a decision that was taken lightly, with discussions taking place with trade unions and no date set for any creche closure.He said: ldquoWe truly appreciate that the cregraveche service, which is supervised by highly-regarded staff, is an incredibly valued service by those who make use of it.ldquoIt is because of this fact, that the decision to withdraw this service has been so incredibly dficult.ldquoOver the past  years, since enjoyrsquos creation, we have retained this service for the benefit of our customers, despite operating at a shortfall.ldquoHowever, as user numbers continue to decline year upon year, the subsequent financial deficit has increased strain on the rest of the organisation.ldquoGiven the funding reductions and additional financial challenges faced by enjoy this year, we have reached the point where we simply cannot continue to subsidise a deficit of this magnitude.ldquoAdditionally, strict adult to child ratios and current charging requirements reduce our capacity of increasing income for this service, and at existing user levels, it is not possible to retain this provision at an affordable cost to customers.Mr Gray has got in touch with enjoyleisure to highlight the ious concerns.Mr Gray said: ldquoI met with a group of women campaigning against the cregraveche closures and listened very carefully to their concerns.ldquoItrsquos clear that whatever the reasons for the withdrawal of the cregraveche service, it will have a signicant impact on those who currently use it.ldquoI have now written to enjoyleisure to highlight the concerns raised with me and ask for a response.Councillor Stuart Currie, leader of the SNP Group on East Lothian Council, was similarly unimpressed with the decision to scrape the creches.He said the SNP Group was supporting the petition calling for enjoyleisure to think again.The Musselburgh councillor said: ldquoIn Haddington, Musselburgh and every other town this damaging decision will hit many people, particularly women, the hardest.Council leader Willie Inneshas written to Gordon Wales, chairman of the enjoyleisure board, to express his concern about the proposed changes.He said: "Following concerns expressed to me by regular users of enjoyleisure facilities about the closure of cregraveches I have written to Gordon Wales outlining the councils position about the importance of access to leisure facilities.ldquoCregraveches provide an important resource for families to be able to fully access a range of leisure activities and I hope alternative measures can be considered."To sign the petition, go to you.degrees.org.uk petitions keep-our-creche

title: plans-lodged-to-turn-former-dunbar-rbs-into-a-sweet-shop
story: Gavin and Susan Love, of Love Sweets and Ices, plan to open a second sweet shop on Dunbar High Street, with a shop within the former Royal Bank of Scotlandpremises.The national bank moved out of  High Street last May, with the premises lying empty ever since.Now plans have been submitted to East Lothian Council looking for alterations to be carried out and the building to be turned into a shop and cafe with outdoor seating.Drawings included in the planning application show little in the way of changes inside the building, with internal walls remaining in place.A seating area would be included at the rear of the building, with benches outside the front in a fenced-off seating area.A managerrsquos office would also be created to the front of the building.Gavin Love, who along with we Susan runs the business at its existing premises of  High Street, said: ldquoThings have been progressing really well.ldquoOur initial plan was to open in March but we have now decided to add some internal seating for sit-in ice cream and we now intend to open in late April early May.Mr and Mrs Love intend to run both shops and use the additional space to provide a wider range of traditional specialised confectionery products and ice cream.Drawings included within the planning application suggest a new lsquoThe Sweetie Bankrsquo sign could be created outside the business.The plans were first highlighted at the townrsquos community council meeting in November last year.Pippa Swan, the grouprsquos chairwoman, was hopeful the business would prove to be a great success.She said: ldquoI had no idea there was such a demand for sweeties and scrumptious things but what a wonderful, fun use of a great building. Irsquom looking forward to it and I am sure it will be a good addition to the street.The bank branch closure was one of  RBS and  NatWest branches to shut following a decision at the end of .The move was widely criticised by local politicians and members of the public, with North Berwickrsquos RBS also closing.

title: belhaven-bays-baywatch-to-patrol-the-beach-this-summer
story: A grant of pound, has been given to Dunbar Surf Le Saving Clubto run the project, which will see training given to volunteers, as well as raising awareness of the risks associated with the coast.The money, from the Big Lottery Fund, will ensure the Dunbar organisation is the first of its kind in Scotland to run a volunteer Beach Surf Lesaving Patrol.Sally Harris, head coach of DSLSC, told the Courier: ldquoWe are absolutely delighted to receive this funding from the National Lottery.ldquoWe will now be able to put together Scotlandrsquos first community-led voluntary surf lesaving beach patrol team in Dunbar.ldquoThe funding will also allow us to continue our preventative education programme, helping to reduce the national coastal drowning statistics.The aims of the Belhaven Bay Community Le Saving Beach Patrol are to provide a lesaving service for the community and visitors, to prevent accidental drowning and injury among beach users.Training will also be given to young people and adults in the community to deliver the services while also raising awareness of the risks associated with using the beach and sea.In , more than  people drowned in the UK.Belhaven Bay, within John Muir Country Park, is a favourite spot for surfers, open-water swimmers and water sports enthusiasts from across the country and beyond.The Beach Patrol will initially operate during the busy summer weekends.Dunbar and East Linton ward member Councillor Norman Hampshire welcomed the scheme.He said: ldquoAs the local ward councillor, I am delighted that Belhaven lsquoBaywatchrsquo with Scotlandrsquos first volunteer Beach Patrol Service are going to start this year.ldquoI would like to congratulate them on their successful application to the Big Lottery.ldquoThis will provide some good training opportunities for young people and adults in the area.George Robertson, chairman of Dunbar and East Linton Area Partnership, wished the club the best of luck.He said: ldquoIt is a worthwhile objective andit makes the beach safer one must applaud it.

title: world-champion-sprinter-maria-lyle-thanks-her-mum-for-rekindling-her-love-of-athletics
story: Maria Lyle ed from the Fazza International Championships in Dubai recently with two gold medals.However, it was just last year that she broke down in tears during her ldquodarkest moment before a major competition.The teenager has lived with diplegic cerebral palsy in her legs almost all her le.The -year-old told the Courier that her mum Susan had been with her throughout her journey, which has seen her represent Great Britain in the Paralympics and Scotland in the Commonwealth Games.Her mum is a PE teacher at Dunbar Primary School and taught Maria.Keen for Maria to be involved as much as her peers, but with little experience of teaching pupils with a disability, Susan looked for ways to deliver lessons which allowed Maria to flourish.Maria said: ldquoWhen I was younger, I struggled quite a lot. Things didnrsquot come quite as naturally for me as they did for my peers and often I ended up feeling a bit rubbish about myself.ldquoThings drastically changed, however, after one PE lesson. We had to complete the multi-stage fitness test .ldquoAs someone who fell over constantly and ended up with cut knees  per cent of the time, you could say I wasnrsquot that keen to join the lesson.ldquoTo everyonersquos surprise, I was the last one left in the test. That was the first time Irsquod ever felt such a sense of achievement. From that moment, running would become a big part of my le.Those short runs started to build Mariarsquos strength.She became European champion in  and within the next four years Paralympic, World and Commonwealth medals followed.But despite all her success, Maria couldnrsquot find the same love for her sport as she had during those early runs with her mum. The teenager became overwhelmed with worry about competing and her concerns impacted her le away from the track.After suffering in silence for years, Maria finally opened up to her mum, who convinced her to seek professional help. She was later diagnosed with having anxiety.Maria, who works at the Scottish Parliament as a committee assistant, said: ldquoMy mum would give up lots of her time, she would lead my sessions and drive me all over the country so I could compete. She would even take time off work to watch me in competitions. Because of this I would get worriedI didnrsquot run well.ldquoIrsquod feel guilty about wasting her time. Disappointing my mum wasnrsquot the only thing I was anxious about. I was worried about my competitors and factors I couldnrsquot control.ldquoBefore the  European Championships, I revealed something to my mum that I had never spoken about before. I broke down and cried for hours expressing how rubbish I felt about myself in both my running and personal le.ldquoRunning had completely taken over and there was nothing positive.ldquoIn my darkest moment, my mum was there for me.ldquoShe was the one who listened for hours. She was the one who hugged me. From that day, my mum and my immediate family have supported me. They have made me realise that there is more to le than running.Susan said that no medal ceremony could compare to seeing her daughter enjoying running again. She said: ldquoMy proudest moment is not Maria winning medals on the world stage, it is probably Maria competing in Glasgow last weekend at the  National Indoor Championships.ldquoFor the first time in years, I saw Maria stand on the start line feeling relaxed and running through the finish line with a smile on her face.ldquoAlong with the support from us as a family and her coach, Jamie Bowie, Maria has turned herself around and is back on track in all areas of her le.

title: little-support-for-idea-of-public-wi-fi-in-town-centres
story: A report to East Lothian Council revealed that moves to increase access to a fast, free public internet service did not win favour with residents.Despite the lack of support, council officers are pushing ahead with their strategy to introduce it across towns in the county.The report into the local authorityrsquos town centre strategy revealed the results of public consultations over a range of actions proposed within the communities.It said: ldquoFor each town centre there was overall support for all the proposed actions, with the exception of the introduction of public Wi-Fi in each town centre, except Haddington which already has public Wi-Fi.In Musselburgh, two-thirds of respondents disagreed with a proposal to introduce it in the town centre, with less than a third agreeing in Tranent. The reaction was similar in Prestonpans and North Berwick, while Dunbar saw the least support, with only one in five backing it.In the majority of towns, the most support was to use statutory action to force private owners of buildings in multiple ownership to have external repairs carried out.Among comments about public Wi-Fi relayed to councillors, one person said: ldquoI really find it surprising that town Wi-Fi has been identied as a possible benefit for the town centre. With excellent G coverage in the town, this would perhaps be more suited at the end of the list of improvements.Another added: ldquoI donrsquot think lack of public Wi-Fi is an issue with G cover widely available.But the council responded: ldquoThe council notes that even with  per centsuperfast broadband coverage [the same goes for G G], affordability will remain a signicant challenge. Consequently, there will still be a requirement for free Wi-Fi across our communities.

title: musselburgh-golf-club-hopes-to-attract-more-women-members
story: Head professional Norman Huguet will lead lessons for women interested in learning to play golf and they will also get the chance to practise their skills on the clubrsquos stand-alone par  beginnersrsquo course.Committee member Linda Smith has organised the initiative, which starts with an open event at the club next Sunday , -pm and -pm.Women can join others also considering taking up golf in a relaxed atmosphere. Everyone is entered into a draw for a free afternoon tea at the club.A block of six lessons for one hour a week then start in April, with clubs provided and trainers allowed. During this time, players have full access to the beginnersrsquo course and all other practice areas.The tuition for a maximum of  women is held on a Tuesday, starting on April , and also on a Wednesday, beginning April , -pm. More classes will be organisedthere is demand.Linda said: ldquoWe want to give people an easy and cheap way to try golf.ldquoPeople might think they need to get golf shoes and equipment. If you decide you want to play, yoursquod get those things over time but, to try golf, you donrsquot need them as we will provide the clubs. We want to take away those barriers.ldquoThere might be a lot of women who would like to try golf but donrsquot know how to go about it.ldquoGroup lessons are a nice way for women to learn and, once the lessons are finished, they have a nice, ready-made group of people that they know in the golf club. So,they go on to join the club, they have people they can play with.ldquoWe will make sure the ladies, during the lessons and after, are integrated into the club. That is something we want to focus on because there is playing on the golf course but there is the golf club which is a dferent thing.ldquoPeople can come into the clubhouse and enjoy the tray bakes and scones, have a coffee and a chat with people, and meet new friends.Linda said the ladiesrsquo section was small with just over  members who play.She added: ldquoDuring the six-week lessons, lady members will help with the lessons and then we can go for a tea or coffee after, so people will be comfortable coming into the clubhouse.ldquoExisting members will also play with the ladies involved in the lessons on the six-hole course.ldquoThe six-hole par- course is great. No one is going to go and watch you playing there. If you miss-hit the ball, which you will when you are learning, there is no one to see you other than other learners.ldquoIt is a non-scary place to learn to play golf.ldquoWe are a really friendly club and people will be made very welcome. If people like it, after the six-week period, they can join the six-hole course or join and be able to play on the championship course.ldquoWe are just hoping that there are enough people out there who want to come and learn.Linda stressed that there were dferent s mapped out on the championship course, including a shorter blue course.Linda said: ldquoThey can play thethey feel is suitable for them.ldquoWe want people to come in and make new friends and use the clubhouse facilities.ldquoIf people want to come and only focus on getting their handicaps down because they are competitive golfers, thatrsquos great as well and there are places for that. Those people donrsquot need these group lessons.Linda added that golf was social, provided exercise in the fresh air and the chance to see wildle and the seasons change.Anyone interested to going along to the open event or to find out more about the package, which costs pound, email sec retary@themusselburghgolf club or call   .

title: labour-peer-launches-plan-to-replace-house-of-lords
story: BaronessPauline Bryan of Partick, a constitutional reform adviser appointed by Jeremy Corbyn, said the move would ensure the Scottish Parliament is ldquono longer subordinateto Westminster.The Labour leader appointed Baroness Bryan to the Lords last year and was designated the partyrsquos lead for updating policy on federalism and Lords reform.At the Scottish Labour conference in Dundee on Saturday, Baroness Bryan launched a paper which sets out her plans for reform.It proposes a new Chamber of the Nations and Regions which should be elected and be fully accountable.It also proposes the ldquofuture relationship between Holyrood and Westminster should be based on partnership and not hierarchy.The document states: ldquoUnder this arrangement there must be common minimum standards across the UK on human rights, employment rights, consumer protection and environmental protection and that the Scottish Parliament should have the power to enhance but never detract from these minimum standards.Baroness Bryan added: ldquoThe point is to change the relationship so that the Scottish Parliament is no longer subordinateto Westminster.ldquoA second Chamber of the Nations and Regions would change the nature of the relations to shared government on the cross territorial issues.ldquoInstead of theHouse of Commons having automatic primacy, this would be a new settlement of shared sovereignty.Mr Corbyn has previously indicated his backing for the move.Press release: New policy paper moves Labour party towards backing full federalism and Lords overhaul at ERS event https:t.co jyVkgXokNi #ScotLabmdash Electoral Reform SocietyMarch , He said: ldquoWe have a House of Lords which is dominated by a small number of people from London and the south east.ldquoI would want to see an elected second chamber that is representative of all regions and nations of the United Kingdom.ldquoI think thatrsquos very, very important. I think it should have an electoral mandate to go with it.Willie Sullivan, of the Electoral Reform Society Scotland, said: ldquoThe piecemeal, ad hoc approach to democratic change in the UK has held us back, with a constant, low-level constitutional crisis, with Scotland and the other nations pitted against Westminster, and vice versa.ldquoThat is not a sustainable relationship and it is time for an approach that puts citizens at the centre, not the needs of politicians. What form this reform takes is up for discussion, but it is good to see parties considering this in the round.ldquoAs this briefing points out, the primary way to reform the bloated, unelected House of Lords is to replace it with a fairly elected revising chamber, with a clearly defined remit and which can speak up for the nations and regions of the whole UK.ldquoVoters are tired of seeing scandal after scandal in the Lords with no way of kicking them out. A much smaller, more effective second chamber would help draw to a close the era of unaccountable power and bring our democracy into the stcentury.

title: labours-richard-leonard-promises-free-bus-network-for-scotland
story: And to help ldquojumpstart struggling bus services ndash which have been hit by falling passenger numbers ndash he called on the Scottish Government to extend free bus passes to those aged under .Mr Leonard told the Scottish Labour conference in Dundee: ldquoIf the SNP donrsquot do it, we will do it on day one of an incoming Scottish Labour government.But he added: ldquoThen we will go further. We will build a proper bus network that connects Scotlandrsquos communities.ldquoLabour will build a free bus network to serve the whole of Scotland.His speech however contained no mention of how much this would cost to deliver, how it would be funded, or when it could be up and running.ldquoLabour will build a free bus network to serve the whole of Scotland. @LabourRichard tells #scotLab . A @scottishlabour Government would start by extending free bus travel to under s # ## pic tpKvVIGmdash Colin SmythMarch , Mr Leonard announced the new policy as he urged party members to stay true to Labourrsquos socialist roots.With UK Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn looking on, he described himself as being ldquoproud to be on the left of politics.Labour has ldquonot come through the adverse electoral storms of the last decade to simply sit back and give up before nationalism, Mr Leonard said.He went on to tell activists the party should ldquostand by our socialist ideals, as it had a ldquovision of the future worth striving for.He insisted: ldquoPeople are turning to us again to fight their corner. And under my leadership, fight it we will.But his speech came at a time when Labour across the UK has come under fire for its stance on Brexit and for failing to tackle anti-Semitism within the party.With several English MPs having quit UK Labour to form The Independent Group, Mr Leonard said this was ldquoa cause for regret.He criticised the UK Government for the ldquocalamity of its approach to Brexit negotiations, as he insisted Labour had been ldquotrying to steer a course through this mess.And he stated: ldquoIf we cannot force Theresa May to change course and accept our credible alternative, let me be absolutely clear, Labour will back a public vote.Mr Leonard was clear that ldquoBrexit is not the only challenge we face as he pledged the next Labour government at Holyrood would ldquobuild a more cohesive society by ending austerity.But he warned his party it must not rely on public disillusionment with the SNP to win back power in Scotland.Scottish nationalists have been in power in Edinburgh since , with Mr Leonard telling delegates: ldquoWe need an awakening.ldquoWe have the vision of how much better our society could be.ldquoAnd I tell you that we cannot rely on an automatic disillusionment with the SNP to do the job for us.Shona Robison, the SNP MSP for Dundee City East, however claimed Labour were ldquocompletely out of touch.She said: ldquoTheyrsquore more interested in fighting each other rather than fighting for the people of Scotland.ldquoIn recent weeks Labour voted against an extra pound million for Scotlandrsquos health service and an pound billion investment in Scottish education. They canrsquot match the SNPrsquos ambition when it comes to delivering for public services.ldquoBoth Jeremy Corbyn and Richard Leonard seem willing to crash us out of the EU in just  daysrsquo time ndash throwing thousands of jobs on the scrapheap and damaging our NHS.ldquoAnd theyrsquore content to team up with the Tories to deny Scotland the right to choose its own future, while we get hammered by Westminster governments we didnrsquot vote for.ldquoNo wonder Labour are trailing a distant third in Scottish politics.

title: footage-reveals-cracks-in-ayrshire-nuclear-reactor
story: The unit at Hunterston B in North Ayrshire has not been operating since the cracks were found to be growing faster than expected.A planned inspection of the graphite bricks that make up the core of reactor threein March last year uncovered new ldquokeyway root cracks.EDF Energy said these have now grown to an average of mm wide.The firm has released footage of the cracks, which was taken in  and .Station director Colin Weir told BBC Scotland: ldquoNuclear safety is our overriding priority and reactor three has been off for the year so that we can do further inspections.ldquoWersquove carried out one of our biggest ever inspection campaigns on reactor three, wersquove renewed our modelling, wersquove done experiments and tests and wersquove analysed all the data from this to produce our safety case that we will submit to the Office for Nuclear Regulation.ldquoWe have to demonstrate that the reactor will always shut down and that it will shut down in an extreme seismic event.

title: Iain Macwhirter  28 days to go and Westminster won   t even reject no deal  let alone back a People   s Vote
story: I could give you a pious expression of naive hope. Tell you that therersquos going to be a referendum on Brexit, that the ERG are back in their box, Jezza has finally come good, and Theresa May has been put in a secure unit. But I canrsquot in all honesty agree with commentators, like the blessed Polly Toynbee, who believe we are now on the road to redemption.Yes, Labour did repeat its promise to hold a referendumJeremy Corbynrsquos ldquoworkable plan of a permanent customs union is rejected ndash as it was in one of last weekrsquos many meaningless votes. Oh, and Labour will support a referendumthere is no General Election. Anda no deal Tory deal looks likely. If, , .ButLabour really wanted to eliminate the threat of no deal, it would have moved heaven and earth to deliver the SNPrsquos motion calling for precisely that.Looking back on this dismal week, the standout, surely, is the arrant insanity of Parliament ndash a rational body of elected representatives ndash failing to take the opportunity to rule out an event which would put the army on the streets, interrupt food and medicine supplies, and cause the loss of tens of thousands of jobs.Yes, the Yvette Cooper Oliver Letwin amendmentwas endorsed by Parliament overwhelmingly, after Theresa May gave it the nod. This means that there will be an extension to Article Parliament doesnrsquot support a deal by March . Well and good. If therersquos one thing the UK Parliament is supremely good at itrsquos failing to agree.It doesnrsquot like Mayrsquos botched deal, the Norway option, EFTA or any other solution that Brussels thinks acceptable. So that means an extension is inevitable. Except that the French president Emmanuel Macron and the Brussels negotiator, Michel Barnier, have made clear that the  countries of the EU , will only contemplate delaying Britainrsquos departure from the EUit is for ldquoa purpose. Holding more meaningless votes, staging more ministerial resignations and arguing on College Green outside Parliament do not, one suspects, constitute a legitimate purpose.Still, everyone seems convinced that an extension is in the bag. This led to largely unwarranted excitement on the Remain side. With Labour calling for a Peoplersquos Voteand Theresa Mayrsquos deadline finally breached, Twitter went into orbit. Lord Adonis all but declared victory in the Battle of Brexit. Europhiles were dancing in the streets, metaphorically at least, and jeering at the nasty Brexiters who had been defeated by the forces of good. It was like the last reel of Lord of the Rings.But such triumphalism was premature. Much as I wish it were the case, there is still no majority in Parliament for a referendum. Stephen K Bush, the political editor of the New Statesman, has been counting them out and counting them back in again and he is adamant that the Labour Brexit rebels will prevent any motion for a referendum passing through Parliament. He says at least  Labour MPs are opposed. Hersquos right.ldquoRebels here is something of a misnomer since there is widespread belief that Brexit is the outcome desired by their leader. Indeed, on one interpretation of last weekrsquos events, Jeremy Corbyn has managed to find a way to secure Brexit while also appearing to support a referendum. This is because what is called the Kyle Wilson amendment.This cross-party proposal, which Labour is minded to support on March , calls for MPs to agree to Theresa Mayrsquos deal , but only on the condition that there is a referendum to validate it. Bingo. Labour can tell all its working-class Brexit supporters in target marginals that, yes, it didnrsquot block Brexit. But Jeremy can also curry favour with the Remainiacs of Islington by appearing to support a Peoplersquos Vote.Itrsquos very clever, but to my mind somewhat bonkers. Why would Labour help pass Theresa Mayrsquos deal, which Jeremy Corbyn has said is worse than no deal, would lose thousands of jobs and would lock the UK into a backstop from which it cannot escape  At least this is what he has said repeatedly in the Commons.Surely, a vote is a vote. Theresa May could legitimately say that her deal has been endorsed by Parliament, and call on Labour to campaign for it in any referendum. Not that she has the slightest intention of calling a referendum.Theresa Mayrsquos strategy is the same as it ever was: not listening, nothing has changed, take it or leave it. It pains me to say it, but the Prime Minister at least has a strategy. It is to run down the clock, while allowing the ious tribes in Parliament and in her Cabinet, to fall out among themselves.Itrsquos working. Labour is moving ever more in the direction of her deal, however much they may deny it. Parliament canrsquot agree on anything.There are tears in Cabinet and more resignations ndash  from the Government so far. But whorsquos counting  The European Research Group ndash that comically misnamed faction of extreme Brexiters ndash has reportedly split over William Rees-Moggrsquos equivocation on the Irish backstop.And while all about is chaos and acrimony, so ticks away the clock until Brexit day. Twenty-eight days at the time of writing. Goodness me, is that really the time  Yes it is. As in the film of the same name, the zombies are stirring.I accept that is an offensive way to describe Nigel Faragersquos ldquoBrexit Betrayal march from Sunderland to London. But it could get nasty on the road.What do I think will happen in the end  As Irsquove been saying in this column since Christmas, I think Parliament will block a no-deal Brexit. There will be an extension of Article , and Labour will probably end up backing Mayrsquos deal, or abstaining on it which amounts to the same thing.If Labour, by some remote chance, continues to reject Mayrsquos deal or its iants, in the meaningful vote on the inglorious twelfth, then I think MPs would still reject a referendum. There is still no majority for one, and Labourrsquos die-hard Brexiters are not for turning.Which makes the most likely option ndash about the only one Theresa May can authorise as PM under her prerogative powers ndash would be to revoke Article . Pull the plug. End it.OK, so thatrsquos wishful thinking on my part. Her Government would fall and precipitate an election. But looking at the chaos that is Brexit, and the lack of time, it seems as good a shout as any, especiallyBrussels reject a meaningless extension.If Britain canrsquot decide how to leave the EU, an extension to Article  would be pointless. The sensible thing to do would be to cancel Brexit, go away, and think again.

title: the-15-must-see-shows-at-the-glasgow-comedy-festival
story: An Audience with Elaine C SmithKings Theatre, Friday  March, .pmpound.Elaine C Smith is totally amazing, shersquos been making people laugh since the bad old days when comedy was a total boys club and shersquos never taken any nonsense while being a brilliant, smart performer. I would never want to bring up a gentlemanrsquos age, but Phil is embracing his elder status in his GICF show - taking aim of modern lersquos abundant and seemingly never ending annoyances, while also slyly questioning whether the lsquogood old daysrsquo were ever that good at all. Go to see one of the geniuses of Scottish comedy at work.Jack Docherty : Miekelson and McGlashan ndash Serious MenKings Theatre, Wednesday  March, .pmpound poundA polis you can laugh at without worrying yoursquoll get chucked in the back of a van, and a fiercely patriotic Scot whorsquoll crack you up rather than drag you into an unfortunate social media spat ndash this promises to be a great night of character comedy from Scot Squad star Jack Docherty. Hersquos from Edinburgh but of course we donrsquot hold that against him ndash wersquore an international festival after all.Siacircn Docksey: CanaryARG at The Vacant Space, Saturday  March, pmpoundThe Vacant Space has an excellent line up of indie comedy from the alternative end of the scene this year and Siacircn Dockseyrsquos show promises to be a silly and subversive treat. Shersquos an up and coming queer millennial who is describing this work-in-progress performance as a ldquoviolent knitting experience   psychic Freudian shitcircus and honestly I donrsquot think I could put it any better than that.Jess Robinson: No FilterOgraveran Moacuter, Friday  March, pmpound poundWhy shell out for concert tickets to see your favourite singing stars when you can hear them all at Jessrsquos show  Shakira, Adele and Kate Bush will all be getting an outing from this hilarious vocal gymnast, whorsquos appearing with a live band to make it a proper night out. Shersquos done everything from Britainrsquos Got Talent to The One Show and none other than Rory Bremner says shersquos the ldquomost exciting impressionist we have.Bobby Mair: UndeterredBlackfriars Basement, Saturday  March, .pmpound Here are all the things you need to know about Bobby Mair: . His show at GICF will be brilliant.James Campbell: The Hilariously Funny World ofhellipEastwood Park Theatre, Saturday  March, pmpound pound Family TicketWe always have a strand of family shows in the festival ndash itrsquos good to remind folk that comedy is not all rude words and blue gags, plus we like to cultivate our audiences from as early an age as possible. Having honed his skills over twenty years at the microphone he has a lot more in his back pocket these days, but the attitude is still unmistakable. Reginald takes on topics that many would shy away from and his material is never less than searingly honest ndash hersquoll make you think almost as hard as you laugh.Robert Florence is Biscuity Boyle: My Bastart Le - One Last Time!Oran Mor, Wednesday  March Wednesday  March, pmpound poundWho knew that Biscuity Boyle had a secret past le as an athlete, raconteur and disco dancer  This is your last chance to see Burnistonrsquos favourite son live on stage with his memoir show which promises laughs, tears and screams of despair before the grand old man of Scottish comedy takes his final bow.Chris Kent: Looking UpBlackfriars Basement, Saturday  March, .pmpound Cork man Chris Kent is one of Irelandrsquos rising stars, a superb storyteller with a lovely laid back style ndash the perfect act for the Blackfriars Basement which is a such a nice, intimate room for comedy. title: what-it-feels-like-to-have-a-stammer
story: The most dficult thing for a person with a stammer to say is their own name. I was often asked to introduce myself and thatrsquos when it would happen. Thatrsquos when I would crumble. The easiest way to describe it is the iceberg effect. At first glance, above the waterline people might not even notice a stammer, but below the surface where people canrsquot see, it can impact everything.My stammer wasnrsquot an issue at first. It developed in my early childhood when I was told that there was a problem with my pronunciation. I was five years old at the time but it didnrsquot control my le. My school report cards always said that I was talkative, confident and participated in all of the classroom activities. I was even given a leading role in a school production.Le changed when I made the move from a small primary school of  pupils to a high school with  people. I sat in class avoiding all eye contact with the teacher, fearing the dreaded moment that I would be asked a question. Jokes were often made by other pupils about my stammer which only made matters worse. I felt misunderstood and it completely ruined my self-esteem. The teachers didnt understand my stammer and some werent even aware that it was a condition. They just assumed that I was nervous.My behaviour soon became self-destructive. My class was asked to take part in a work shadowing competition were the top ten reports would be selected and the winners were expected to give a presentation in front of everyone. I couldnt think of anything worse. I took matters into my own hands and purposely sabotaged my report by adding in mistakes to ensure that I wouldnrsquot be picked.I used to be a teacher, I ended up homeless - football saved my leWhen I was studying at university, I worried about everything from being knocked back on nights out with my friends to buying train tickets. I thought that I would never get a job or make anything of my le. I had a good circle of friends, but it was always in the back of my mind that I was going to be made fun of by others. It reached the point were I knew that I had to take charge of the situation and not allow it to take over my le any more.Although there are speech therapists, there isnt a great deal of support for people living with stammers. I set up a support group in  for other people with the same concerns. People from all walks of le attend and share their stories. Each monthly session looks at ways to cope with everyday situations that stammers can make dficult. It explores ways to desensitise stammering, build peoplersquos confidence and help them manage stress.At one point, speaking situations were the first thing on my mind in the morning and the last thing on my mind at night. Now, I work for the NHS in a job where Irsquom required to speak in public and give presentations. Irsquom at a stage where I often find that I actually enjoy public speaking which is something I never thought Irsquod say. Irsquove learned how to overcome my stammer by reaching out and connecting with others.Visit stammeringscotland.orgSOPHIE MCLEAN

title: public-house-by-nico-great-western-road-glasgow-reviewed-by-ron-mackenna
story: GlasgowI LIKE to think I spot the flaw with The Public House by Nico almost right away. Hang on, I say to Gordon and Gerry, it doesnrsquot look much like a pub. They pause their deep conversation on the travails of The Celtic only long enough to look at me as though Irsquove just fallen through the ceiling. Hmm.As one bottle of wine has already been finished and Glasgow celebrity chef owner Nico Simonersquos vino mark-up for the night is going to be boosted by lingering over a second ndash ordered by the glass ndash I suppose it doeslike a pub. Albeit on this dreich Tuesday evening one that is so quiet and lacking in atmosphere that I can feel the metaphoric wind whistle round the high backs of themany chairs.Have you read my book about Celtic, I drop into their intense chat, referring to a forgettable tome myself and my old chum Carlos Alba wrote when we were still treading the boards as reporters. Double blankos all round. Sigh.Actually, by the time I make that non-pub revelation we will have been here so long that the waiter will soon bring the bill unprompted and the Public House will be about to fill with the aroma of the powerful fluids the staff are using to clean down that open stainless steel kitchen over there. And I will be wondering what exactly it is about The Public House that does not entirely convince me.Itrsquos not the food. Because when we were fully engaged in talking about work, for the first couple of hours anyway, that conversation was only interrupted by what was going on in our mouths.Smash: Arbroath Smokie croquetteshellip possibly the worldrsquos juiciest, tastiest fish fingers. Bang: sprouting broccoli, pickled walnuts and English feta, the broccoli tasting as though it has been preserved in garlic and oil sending me off on one about how my old man used to make jars of its deliciousness every year. Wallop: Hispi cabbage, black garlic, ewes cheese. That gooey, rich, garlic sauce kick-starting the thick pale cabbage leaves and salty cheese into a tantalising threesome across the palate.We paused for a full two minutes on the Pork scratchings, to consider how Gordon had reached a ripe old age without ever tasting these puffy, saltypleasures. And I even managed to set pulses slowing with a familiar monologue on how Nicorsquos triple cookedchips, crumbly inside, crispy outside, are in fact not bloody chips at all but potato Jenga, or batons. More blankos here.Joanna Blythman reviews Lady Libertine, EdinburghThat little smoked ham hough sandwich  Micro assembly, painstakingly tweezered into place, fresh piccalilli on the side but way, way too salty.The sea bass though  A full-size steamed bok choi sprawling languidly beside it, slivers of pickled chilli sauntering by, soy and miso puddles. Boof, the fish fillets crisped to perfection, coloured to appetising and, hurrah, properly seasoned. They have sous vidersquod that pork chop to textured perfection too flash fried its crisply coloured edges, poached a purpley heritage carrot and crisped some sage for the sprinkling over of.The last time I had a decent pork chop was at Dinner in London and I got whacked an absolute fortune for that. This is a tenner. If I wanted to be picky Irsquod say only this: Irsquod pay maybe twice as much for one cooked exactly the same way but with a better quality of pork. It would make a big dference.Desserts then  We have had a few. But then again too few to mention. I find mine creamy fluffy and the rhubarb fool in particular pretty forgettable. But then I wanted the banana crumble thing that after even more blankos, this time from the staff, turned out not to be on the right menu or something like that and definitely not available.Oh, hey, Irsquove finally worked out whatrsquos missing. Nico. And a bit of pizzaz about the place. Especially as it doesnrsquot really feel like a hip and happening gastropub.Public House by Nico Great Western RoadGlasgowwww.publichousebynico bookMenu: Nico of Six by Nico and other such ventures brings his top dishes to Glasgowrsquos Great Western Road with big flavours on small-plates-a-go-go. Arbroath Smokie fish fingers, sauteed broccoli with walnut. Good stuff.  Service: We caught them early in the week and while the staff were fine there wasnrsquot much sparkle about the experience, possibly better at the weekends.  Atmosphere: See above. Itrsquos doesnrsquot feel to me much like a public house gastropub no matter how insistent the name and when semi-empty felt over-furnished and under-whelming. At weekends may fly.  Price: Small plates mean big bills and an easier le for the kitchen, but everything was packed with thought and flavour so for once I didnt grudge paying around pound a plate.  Food: More evolutionary than revolutionary but Glasgow probably needs this. Some great dishes including that sprouting broccoli, pickled walnut and English feta, those hispi and those cheeky Arbroath Smokie fingers.

title: jeremy-corbyn-snp-neglecting-the-poor-to-chase-independence
story: The Labour leader will say the real ide in society "is not between people who voted yes or no for independence",but between law-abiding workersand the tax-dodging rich.He will also tell his partyrsquos Scottish conference that ldquoclimate change is a class issue as it will have the greatest impact on the poor and marginalised and addressing it is a ldquosocialist priority.Mr Corbyn is due to give the closing speech on the first day of the gathering in Dundee.:Jeremy Corbyn backed Scottish independence during a private conversation with Mhairi BlackHe is due to tell delegates: ldquoThe truth about Labour is, wersquore not obsessed by constitutional questions, like the others are.ldquoWersquore obsessed with tackling the problems people face in their daily lives. Ending insecurity at work. Ending poverty wages. Ending the cuts to our public services.ldquoBecause we believe that the real ide in our society is not between people who voted yes or no for independence. And itrsquos not between people who voted to remain or to leave the EU.ldquoThe real ide is between the many ndash who do the work, create the wealth and pay their taxes ndash and the few, who set the rules, reap the rewards and dodge their taxes.ldquoSo let me spell it out: our mission is to back the working class, in all its ersity.On climate change, he will say: ldquoWe are facing a climate crisis. Therersquos no bigger threat to our future. And fundamentally, the destruction of our climate is a class issue.ldquoItrsquos working class communities that suffer the worst pollution and the worst air quality. Itrsquos working class people who will lose their jobs as resources run dry. And it is working class people who will be left behind as the rich escape rising sea levels.ldquoBig corporations will never do anything serious about it. The Conservative government will never do anything serious about it either.ldquoBut Labour will make it a central objective of our industrial strategy.ldquoWe need to reduce our net emissions to zero by  at the latest - itrsquos not just an ecological priority, itrsquos a socialist priority too.:Jeremy Corbyn seeks to reach out to independence supportersAnd on austerity he will tell the Caird Hall: ldquoWe shouldnrsquot have a situation where a quarter of children in Scotland are living in poverty. We shouldnrsquot have thousands of Scottish young people without a home. We shouldnrsquot have le expectancy in Britain falling.ldquoWhat is happening to our country  Itrsquos not only an economic and social disaster, it is a moral outrage.Shona Robison, the SNP MSP for Dundee City East, said: "Jeremy Corbyn is completely out of touch he is with whatrsquos going on in Scotland. The fact is, Labour are far more interested in fighting each other rather than fighting for the people of Scotland.ldquoBoth Jeremy Corbyn and their leader in Scotland are willing to crash us out of the EU in just  daysrsquo time ndash throwing thousands of jobs on the scrapheap and damaging our NHS. ldquoAnd theyrsquore content team up with the Tories to deny Scotland the right to choose its own future, while we get hammered by Westminster governments we didnrsquot vote for.ldquoNo wonder Labour are trailing a distant third in Scottish politics.

title: unspun-the-political-diary
story: MR Bercow was less flattering after PMQs as Nats raged at Theresa May claiming they had no mandate for independence. Reluctantly he took a point of order from Angus Brendan Macneil. ldquoItrsquos a matter of fact, itrsquos matter of truth, that the Prime Minister, what she said, is not the situation in Scotland, burbled the Western Isles MP. ldquoThe Prime Minister said there was not a mandate. There is a mandate for independence.Thatrsquos the fact! Mr Bercow paused. ldquoIrsquom not sure that greatly added to the intellectual quality of the exchanges, he sighed.EQUALLY waspish was SNP Brexit Secretary Mike Russell as he noised up Tory MSPs for slavishly backing Theresa Mayrsquos Brexit deal. ldquoWe now know that the Scottish Conservatives will be fighting the next election under the slogan lsquoObey Mrs Mayrsquo, he sneered. ldquoI look forward to seeing that slogan on endless posters, perhaps with a picture of a Dalek. Miaow.WE all know Jeremy Corbyn hates the media, but did Scottish Labour have to make it quite so obvious at this weekendrsquos conference in Dundee  The party scheduled both JCrsquos big speech and a juicy fringe meeting at the very end of Friday, making it impossible for thirsty hacks to write them up and then make it to the ldquomedia reception at .pm. But what of the great Muscovite himself  Unspun hears a group of business people were recently out for lunch in Aberdeen when Eck made eye contact and invited himself over to their table, sat down and started sampling their grub, not unlike the cityrsquos seagulls. title: herald-diary-is-this-the-poshest-football-chant-ever
story: SCOTTISH football fans are getting a bad time in the press these days, so we look back on happier times with these Diary stories about fans in the past, including the supporter who phoned to tell us: "I cant stand these people who hate football, but still go along to games to cause trouble and ruin it for everybody ."Bloody referees hellip"Ripping yarnIT was our feature writer chum on The Herald, Teddy Jamieson, who got to the bottom of the oft-told tale of flash Charlie Nicholas, when at Celtic in the late seventies, tearing up a pound note in front of a fan who was giving him grief to show he was rich and didnt care.Teddy asked Charlie about it who said: "I think I was , . I shouldnt have been allowed in the pub. There was this guy giving me earache all night. Im better than you. Im better than you. I went into the gents and he was right at my back and he gave it to me again. So I took the pound and said, Can you do this  I ripped it up and threw it on the ground and walked out. He came out and went to his mates looking a bit sheepish. My point was made and I sprinted straight back into the toilet to get the pound note to Sellotape it up.All aboardA READER once heard a fan discussing his trip to an away game in the SPL, and how he managed to cadge a lt back on a supporters bus. "So they had a spare seat " asked his pal. "Aye," the chap replied. "It was full originally, but fortunately someone got lted.Going higherNOT all football chants are foul-mouthed. When The Herald ran a story about Mortons mascot Cappie the Cat having its tail ripped off when it caught it in the dressing-room door, and club medics sewing it back on, a reader phoned to express outrage that it had not been treated more humanely and taken to a vets. The reporter gently explained that it was a costumed fan and not a real cat.Suits youTHERE were a few Diary stories about Rangers epic struggle to climb back through all the leagues after going into administration. Many Rangers fans followed them on the comeback trail, and boasted that the club set a record for the largest crowd in the world at any fourth tier football game. However a Celtic fan phoned to tell us: "Thats a bit like boasting about being the best-dressed man in Albania.And when Brechin equalised against Rangers before eventually losing, the Brechin fans were chanting: "Are you Forfar in disguise Work itWE should, of course, also mention Junior Football. Our chum Graham Scott was at an Auchinleck Talbot v Beith game in the old mining village when an Auchinleck fan, frustrated by a delay in the game, shouted: "Cmon ref, ahve ma work to get up for in the morning." A Beith fan immediately shouted over: "You dont live in Auchinleck then Blowing in the windAND, finally, the Tartan Army. A Renfrewshire reader was in Paris for a France v Scotland game when he saw one of his kilted brethren wearing a T-shirt with "ventilateur" printed on the back. Our reader could only surmise that the chap had used an electronic dictionary to find out the French word for fan and have it printed as a welcoming gesture. Alas ventilateur is of the electric fan iety.THOSE WERE THE DAYS - : The show of hands that turned Bearsden into a burgh

title: richard-leonard-labour-cannot-rely-on-snp-delcine
story: The Scottish Labour leader will say there is no ldquoiron law that the SNPrsquos popularity will wane before the next Holyrood election in , and winning will take a hard fight.Even after being out of office for  years, he will say Scotland Labour is only now ldquogetting back to where we should have been in terms of traditional support.A Panelbase poll this week showed support for Scottish Labour continuing to slide.On the second of three days in Dundee, Mr Leonard will also highlight the cityrsquos industrial closures as he calls for a more progressive agenda for workersrsquo rights.Michelin closed its tyre factory in November with the loss of  jobs, while the construction services firm McGill and Co went into administration last month, axing almost  jobs.Referring to Scottish Labourrsquos route back to power, Mr Leonard will say: ldquoWe cannot rely on an automatic disillusionment with the SNP to do the job for us. There is no iron law, there is no inevitability. Butwe work for it, industrially and politically, we can achieve it.ldquoBecause I tell you that we make our own history. We are getting back to where we always should have been, the party of communities and the party of workers.He will tell delegates at the Caird Hall about meeting McGill workers a few weeks ago.ldquoThey told me they had been let down: badly let down by the companyrsquos bank which foreclosed an overdraft and badly let down by the Scottish Government, which could have stepped in to rescue these jobs, but who sat back.ldquoThe SNP tell us we shouldnrsquot talk about workersrsquo rights because they are reserved. But [bad] practices are commonplace on public contracts funded by the Scottish Government.ldquoIt is about time we had a Scottish Government prepared to use its powers, including through public procurement to drive up employment standards and working practices on these contracts to build our hospitals, our roads, and our railway infrastructure.

title: corbyns-constitutional-adviser-tells-him-to-create-partnership-government-with-scotland
story: Baroness Pauline Bryan of Partick appointed by Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn last year explicitly to develop the partyrsquos constitutional policy, is recommending greater devolution of power to Scotland - by ensuring the future relationship between Holyrood and Westminster is based on an equal footing.For the first time she will today launch her initial lsquopartnership not hierarchyrsquo proposals for change to the Labour Party, which would involve creating a Chamber of the Nations and Regions to replace the House of Lords in a move that Baroness Bryan believes would mean the Scottish Parliament was no longer subordinate to Westminster.It comes as previously unreleased poll for the Electoral Reform Society by BMG shows that, when dont knows are excluded, support for an elected upper chamber sits at % for SNP voters and % for Conservatives.ERS says that suggest that Lords reform could be a vote winner for the party . A majority of all main partiesrsquo supporters backed an elected second chamber.The Bryan paper that kicks off Labours review of its constitutional policy is set to take the party much closer to backing full federalism and a new constitutional settlement for the UK "based on the commitment to redistribute power and wealth, and that takes account of the consequences of Brexit".In her analysis of future principles, she says a new federal set-up will "move from the existing model, where power is devolved from the central state to Scotland".Baroness Bryan, who is the designated lead for updating the partyrsquos policy on federalism and Lords reform says the lsquopartnershiprsquo model for Westminster and Scotland would be backed by the reformed second chamber.The peer adds: "The point is to change the relationship so that the Scottish Parliament is no longer subordinate to Westminster. A second chamber of the Regions and Nations would change the nature of the relations to shared government on the cross territorial issues."UK-wide, ldquoInstead of the House of Commons having automatic primacy, this would be a new settlement of shared sovereignty, Baroness Bryan says.She believes a reformed ndash most-likely directly elected ndash second chamber would have a key role in this, bringing the nations and regions together to agree what powers should be devolved and which should be shared.Willie Sullivan, director of ERS Scotland, said: ldquoThe piecemeal, ad hoc approach to democratic change in the UK has held us back, with a constant, low-level constitutional crisis: with Scotland and the other nations pitted against Westminster, and vice versa."That is not a sustainable relationship and it is time for an approach the puts citizens at the centre, not the needs of politicians. What form this reform takes is up for discussion, but it is good to see parties considering this in the round.ldquoAs this briefing points out, the primary way to reform the bloated, unelected House of Lords is to replace it with a fairly-elected revising chamber, with a clearly defined remit and which can speak up for the nations and regions of the whole UK."Voters are tired of seeing scandal after scandal in the Lords with no way of kicking them out. A much-smaller, more effective second chamber would help draw to a close the era of unaccountable power and bring our democracy into the st century.Bryans other key claims include concerns that the Scottish Parliament has gained additional powers in response to political pressures, which can be "curtailed as easily as they were granted".She says that while the Sewel convention established that Westminster would not legislate on devolved issues without the express consent of the Scottish Parliament, "we have seen from the repatriation of powers through Brexit that this may not always be adhered to".She also states that local government in Scotland has lost powers to increasing centralisation by the Scottish Government.Nancy Platts, co-ordinator of Politics for the Many ndash the trade union campaign for political reform ndash said: ldquoThis is a fundamental step [forward] in developing Labourrsquos thinking on constitutional reform. Labour must now adopt these proposals as the starting point to ensuring that our politics works for the many, not an unelected few.The report will be unveiled at a Labour fringe meeting titled: "Remaking the state: Transforming Scotland for Worker and Citizen Power".Mass poll by BMG for ERS.
